thread.title_full: Ruben Tejada becomes rallying cry in emotional Mets moment | New York Post

author: Howie Kussoy
title: Ruben Tejada becomes rallying cry in emotional Mets moment
text:
As if emotion would be lacking in the Mets’ first playoff game in nine years.
Though Chase Utley ensured Ruben Tejada wouldn’t play again this postseason — having fractured the Mets shortstop’s right fibula during Saturday’s Game 2 of the NLDS — Tejada still played a significant role in the Mets’ 13-7 Game 3 win over the Dodgers, inspiring his teammates and igniting the Citi Field crowd after limping out with a cast on his leg and a cane in his hand to join his teammates during pregame introductions.
The first-ever playoff game at Citi Field included the largest home crowd the Mets had seen since leaving Shea Stadium, with nearly every seat filled by the time both teams were being introduced.
The Dodgers came first, with the hostility and volume increasing until the desired target — Utley — was announced. Finally, fans could take out their anger on the longtime Phillie, who was responsible for the game-changing — and what appeared to be a series-changing — tackle/slide of Tejada.
For Mets fans, nothing looked like it could be so much fun, unleashing an overwhelming wave of visceral emotion and unfiltered language. Then, the Mets were introduced. And love was that much stronger.
For days, replays showed Tejada’s season ending and leg cracking over and over, the shortstop just a talking point for the state of the game. Monday, he became more.
Exiting the dugout to step onto the field, Tejada became a rallying cry, getting the final honor to join his teammates he could only cheer on for the rest of the fall, hobbling toward the first-base line with a smile and a blue-and-orange cane.
While teammates clapped for the 25-year-old — who has spent all six of his major league seasons with the Mets — Tejada turned to a standing-only crowd and tipped his cap, with many of the fans holding up pictures of Tejada’s face and signs that read “Win for Ruben.”
Tejada joined his teammates and then was carried through the dugout, piggy-back style, by replacement shortstop Mark Reynolds.
Tejada is expected to spend the next six to eight weeks in the cast, but is expected to make a full recovery by spring training.
